'''Lillian Glinn''' (May 10, 1902 – July 22, 1978)<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=6ZNfAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA524&lpg=PA524&dq=glinn&source=bl&ots=8GMtaVHmc6&sig=OyJy1dew7qr53yZ4N8LWcyNiYVI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PXU4U5mUK4fhsAS-u4DoDg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=glinn&f=false ''Blues: A Regional Experience''] by Bob L. Eagle and Eric S. LeBlanc, p. 524.</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[country blues]] singer and songwriter. She spent most of her career in [[Black people|black]] [[vaudeville]].<ref name="AMG"/> Her most popular recordings were "Black Man Blues," "Doggin' Me Blues" and "Atlanta Blues."<ref name="TSHA">{{cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fgl21 |title=Lillian Glinn |author=James Head |date= |work=Handbook of Texas Online |publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=September 20, 2011}}</ref> The blues historian, [[Paul Oliver]], commented that there are a number of women blues singers who "deserve far greater recognition than they have had" and that one such was Lillian Glinn.<ref name="Oliphant">{{cite book
| first= Dave
| last= Oliphant
| year= 1996
| title= Texan Jazz
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Texas Press 
| location= Austin, Texas
| isbn= 0-292-76044-2
| page= 71}}</ref>

==Biography==
Glinn was born in [[Hillsboro, Texas]], [[United States]], and later moved to [[Dallas]].<ref name="TSHA"/>

She was first noticed singing [[Spiritual (music)|spirituals]] in church by her future fellow performer Hattie Burleson. Under Burleson's guidance, Glinn became successful in vaudeville, and by 1927 was signed to a [[recording contract]] by [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]. Glinn took part in six separate recording sessions in a two-year period up to 1929.<ref name="AMG"/> She recorded a total of twenty-two tracks.<ref name="TSHA"/> Her speciality was singing slow blues ballads utilising her rich and heavy [[contralto]] [[Human voice|voice]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p80394|pure_url=yes}}|title=Lillian Glinn|author=Steve Huey |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 20, 2011}}</ref> Her songs concentrated on the harsher side of life and sometimes included [[sexual innuendo]].<ref name="TSHA"/>  Her recordings gained her national recognition, and included her April 1928 recording of "Shake It Down".<ref name="Oliphant"/>  Her sessions took place variously in [[New Orleans]] and [[Atlanta]], as well as her home base of Dallas.<ref name="TSHA"/>

The author and researcher, David Evans, noted that "it is quite likely that many of Lillian Glinn's blues without any listed composer were her own material. If so, she would be the exception among Columbia's female blues singers", he concluded.<ref>{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Evans
| year= 1982
| title= Big Road Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of California Press 
| location= Los Angeles, California
| isbn= 0-520-03484-8
| page= 67}}</ref> 

Following this period of activity, Glinn retreated back to church based life, and moved to [[California]] where she married the Rev. O.P. Smith.  Her future became distant from her previous professional career.<ref name="TSHA"/> 

Her entire recorded work was made available in 1994 by [[Document Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/complete-recorded-works-1927-1929-mw0000107808/credits |title=Complete Recorded Works (1927-1929) - Lillian Glinn | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1994-06-02 |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> 

She was interviewed and photographed by Paul Oliver in 1971.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= Paul 
| last= Oliver
| year= 2009
| title= Barrelhouse blues: location recording and the early traditions of the blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= BasicCivitas Books 
| location= New York
| isbn= 978-0-465-00881-0
| page= 77}}</ref>
